Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SHINE--Observations and Modeling of the Longitudinal Extent and Variation of Multi-Spacecraft Solar Energetic Particle (SEP) Events
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research team will investigate the relative roles of shock acceleration, flare acceleration, suprathermal particle composition, and particle transport as a function of position (along the shock and/or the longitudinal distance from the solar source region). The relative contributions of flare and shock acceleration to solar energetic particle (SEP) events and their resulting compositional signatures are as yet undetermined, and this fact provides the motivation for this work. The research team will use observations of specific individual SEP events obtained from multiple spacecraft, rather than attempting to infer phenomenology through statistical studies of many events measured by a single spacecraft under varying conditions, as has been done in the past. This approach will allow a more accurate determination of the driving coronal mass ejection's source region and of its related properties. The team's analysis technique will also provide a more global view of solar activity and non-local effects, which may play an important role in the generation of SEP events and in determining their longitudinal extent. This effort will directly address open scientific questions regarding SEP composition and particle transport.

Understanding the production, composition, and extent of SEP events is critical for accurate predictions of space weather and its potential impact on astronauts and satellites. The team will disseminate their scientific results through published articles, scientific talks, and the web pages associated with the relevant NASA spacecraft missions. This project will contribute to the training of a postdoctoral researcher as a co-investigator at George Mason University, and, through an international collaboration, a graduate student in Germany. The team will also supervise and train students at the University of Arizona and the Naval Research Laboratory who will work on this project. The Lead Principal Investigator at the California Institute of Technology is an active participant in "Solar Week," a local program designed to encourage high school girls to pursue careers in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mankind is every day more dependent on technology, which makes us more susceptible to certain types of solar-related phenomena. Solar Energetic Particles (SEP), the subject matter of this proposal, can be produced and accelerated during, for example, a Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) event, and present a serious threat both to humans in space and to the operation of space-based instrumentation. To accomplish the objectives of this Proposal different approaches were employed. The results contribute to the understanding of the connection between solar activity and SEP characteristics/properties, which is a scientific and pragmatic goal for both the space science and the space weather prediction communities.

In the first effort we studied the longitudinal extent of the SEP events by analyzing an hour-long eruption of a fast and wide CME using high-cadence, high-resolution, multi-point imaging from the Solar-Terrestrial Relations Observatory (STEREO) and the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO). The combination of ultraviolet and white-light images of the lower corona revealed that during the initial phase, when the flanks of the CME expand laterally, the EUV disturbance tracks the CME flanks, moving along the solar surface with speeds of ~450 km/sec. The ultraviolet and white-light data was combined with a comprehensive study of the velocity dispersion of energetic particles measured in situ by particle detectors at the location of STEREO-A (STA) and at the first Lagrange point (L1). This investigation demonstrated that the delayed solar particle release times at STA and L1 were consistent with the time required by the CME (i.e., about 30–40 min) to perturb the corona over a wide range of longitudes. In conclusion, this study revealed the association between the longitudinal extent of the perturbed corona (as seen in both EUV and white light imaging) and the longitudinal extent of the SEP event in the heliosphere (Rouillard et al., ApJ, 752:44, 2012. DOI: 10.1088/0004-637X/752/1/44).

Next, the relation between shocks and SEP events was investigated. To that aim, a novel data-driven analysis technique to determine the extent of shocks in the lower corona was developed. Briefly, the technique allows us to determine whether a coronal shock is magnetically connected to an in-situ probe simply by using solar images and straightforward models of the large-scale magnetic field. In particular, the time-variation of the shock geometry and velocity can be computed along all magnetic field lines associated with SEP events measured in-situ. In this way, the technique enables the comparison of the evolving properties of shocks and SEPs (e.g., heavy ion content, intensity, timing and longitudinal extent). In addition, it allows us to estimate the magnetic field entrained in a CME because the magnetic connectivity between a spacecraft and a shock is linked to the structure and evolution of the magnetic obstacle within a CME. In summary, the technique promotes much easier analytical investigations of future events and their 3D structure (Savani et al., Space Weather, 13, 374, 2015. DOI: 10.1002/2015SW001171).

The final study was aimed at bringing to light the influence of the environment in the generation, kinematic properties, and longitudinal extent of SEPs. Therefore, the role of ambient coronal structures on the development of several homologous CME events and their associated shocks was studied. The analysis was based on high-resolution multi-wavelength imaging and radio spectral observations taken from two vantage points (in quadrature).
